messageBody:
Arun J wrote:
>
> Thanks guyz for the direction..
>
> Paul, I like your example Peel-> Cut->Eat....exactly they themselves
> are tests and also are dependent..

I wish I had thought of that particular example but I was just quoting
what I thought was the best example from the reference.

Why is it often considered dangerous and bad OO not to have isolation?
Well if I have a bug in testPeel (it doesn't set up a variable that is
later needed in one of the dependent tests) the error will typically
show up later in the test run, e.g. testEat() will fail due to a bug
in testPeel(). The bad OO can come about because once you start using
dependent tests, some people have a tendency to use "global variables"
to pass intermediate results along the chain rather than provide good
OO encapsulation. So caveat emptor ...

To quote from some more detail from Martin Fowler
(http://www.martinfowler.com/bliki/JunitNewInstance.html):

"Isolation provides several advantages.

* Any combination of tests can be run in any order with the same results.
* You never have a situation where you're trying to figure out why one test
failed and the cause is due to the way another test is written.
* If one test fails, you don't have to worry about it leaving debris that
will cause other tests to fail. That helps prevent cascading errors that
hides the real bug."

Have a look at that reference for an interesting discussion.

Paul.
